trans-unit.source: Application Objects and Service Principal Objects
trans-unit.target: Application Objects and Service Principal Objects

trans-unit.source: A discussion of the relationship between Application objects and ServicePrincipal objects in Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: A discussion of the relationship between Application objects and ServicePrincipal objects in Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: This diagram illustrates the relationship between an Application object and a ServicePrincipal object in the context of an sample application called HR app.
trans-unit.target: This diagram illustrates the relationship between an Application object and a ServicePrincipal object in the context of an sample application called HR app.

trans-unit.source: There are three tenants: Adatum, the tenant that develops the app, and Contoso and Fabrikam, the tenants that consume the HR app.
trans-unit.target: There are three tenants: Adatum, the tenant that develops the app, and Contoso and Fabrikam, the tenants that consume the HR app.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Relationship between an Application object and a ServicePrincipal object</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Relationship between an Application object and a ServicePrincipal object</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When you register an app in the Azure Management Portal, two objects are created in your directory tenant:
trans-unit.target: When you register an app in the Azure Management Portal, two objects are created in your directory tenant:

trans-unit.source: Application object: This object represents a definition for your app.
trans-unit.target: Application object: This object represents a definition for your app.

trans-unit.source: You can find a detailed description of its properties in the Application Object section below.
trans-unit.target: You can find a detailed description of its properties in the Application Object section below.

trans-unit.source: ServicePrincipal object: This object represents an instance of your app in your directory tenant.
trans-unit.target: ServicePrincipal object: This object represents an instance of your app in your directory tenant.

trans-unit.source: You can apply policies to ServicePrincipal objects, including assigning permissions to the ServicePrincipal that allow the app to read your tenant’s directory data.
trans-unit.target: You can apply policies to ServicePrincipal objects, including assigning permissions to the ServicePrincipal that allow the app to read your tenant’s directory data.

trans-unit.source: Whenever you change your Application object, the changes are also applied to the associated ServicePrincipal object in your tenant.
trans-unit.target: Whenever you change your Application object, the changes are also applied to the associated ServicePrincipal object in your tenant.

trans-unit.source: If your application is configured for external access, changes to the application object are not reflected in a consumer tenant’s ServicePrincipal until the consumer tenant removes access and grants access again.
trans-unit.target: If your application is configured for external access, changes to the application object are not reflected in a consumer tenant’s ServicePrincipal until the consumer tenant removes access and grants access again.

trans-unit.source: In the diagram above, Step "1" is the process of creating the Application and ServicePrincipal objects.
trans-unit.target: In the diagram above, Step "1" is the process of creating the Application and ServicePrincipal objects.

trans-unit.source: In Step 2, when a company admin grants access, a ServicePrincipal object is created in the company's Azure AD tenant and is assigned the directory access level that the company admin granted.
trans-unit.target: In Step 2, when a company admin grants access, a ServicePrincipal object is created in the company's Azure AD tenant and is assigned the directory access level that the company admin granted.

trans-unit.source: In Step 3, the consumer tenants of an app (such as Contoso and Fabrikam) each have their own ServicePrincipal object that represents their instance of the app.
trans-unit.target: In Step 3, the consumer tenants of an app (such as Contoso and Fabrikam) each have their own ServicePrincipal object that represents their instance of the app.

trans-unit.source: In this example, they each have a ServicePrincipal that represents the HR app.
trans-unit.target: In this example, they each have a ServicePrincipal that represents the HR app.

trans-unit.source: The following tables list all the properties of an application object and includes important details for developers.
trans-unit.target: The following tables list all the properties of an application object and includes important details for developers.

trans-unit.source: These properties apply to web applications, web APIs, and native client applications that are registered with Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: These properties apply to web applications, web APIs, and native client applications that are registered with Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Property
trans-unit.target: Property

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Name
trans-unit.target: Name

trans-unit.source: Display name of the app.
trans-unit.target: Display name of the app.

trans-unit.source: Required property in the Add Application wizard.
trans-unit.target: Required property in the Add Application wizard.

trans-unit.source: Logo
trans-unit.target: Logo

trans-unit.source: An app logo that represents your app or company.
trans-unit.target: An app logo that represents your app or company.

trans-unit.source: This logo allows external users to more easily associate the grant access request with your app.
trans-unit.target: This logo allows external users to more easily associate the grant access request with your app.

trans-unit.source: When uploading a logo, please adhere to the specifications in the Upload logo wizard.
trans-unit.target: When uploading a logo, please adhere to the specifications in the Upload logo wizard.

trans-unit.source: If you don’t supply a logo, a default logo appears.
trans-unit.target: If you don’t supply a logo, a default logo appears.

trans-unit.source: External access
trans-unit.target: External access

trans-unit.source: Determines whether users in external organizations are allowed to grant your app single sign-on and access to data in their organization's directory.
trans-unit.target: Determines whether users in external organizations are allowed to grant your app single sign-on and access to data in their organization's directory.

trans-unit.source: This control affects only the ability to grant access.
trans-unit.target: This control affects only the ability to grant access.

trans-unit.source: It does not change access that has already been granted.
trans-unit.target: It does not change access that has already been granted.

trans-unit.source: Only Company Administrators can grant access.
trans-unit.target: Only Company Administrators can grant access.

trans-unit.source: Property
trans-unit.target: Property

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: App ID URI
trans-unit.target: App ID URI

trans-unit.source:
A unique logical identifier for your app. Required property in the Add Application wizard.

Because the App ID URI is a logical identifier, it does not need to resolve to an Internet address. It is presented by your app when sending a single sign-on request to Azure AD. Azure AD identifies your app and sends the sign-on response (a SAML token) to the Reply URL that was provided during app registration. Use the App ID URI value to set the wtrealm property (for WS-Federation) or the Issuer property (for SAML-P) when making a sign-in request. The App ID URI must be a unique value in your organization’s Azure AD.

Note: When enabling an app for external users, the value of the App ID URI of the app must be an address in one of your directory’s verified domains. As a result, it cannot be a URN. This safeguard prevents other organizations from specifying (and taking) unique property that belongs to your organization. During development, you can change your App ID URI to a location in your organization’s initial domain (if you haven’t verified a custom/vanity domain), and update your app to use this new value. The initial domain is the 3-level domain that you create during sign up, such as contoso.onmicrosoft.com.
trans-unit.target:
A unique logical identifier for your app. Required property in the Add Application wizard.

Because the App ID URI is a logical identifier, it does not need to resolve to an Internet address. It is presented by your app when sending a single sign-on request to Azure AD. Azure AD identifies your app and sends the sign-on response (a SAML token) to the Reply URL that was provided during app registration. Use the App ID URI value to set the wtrealm property (for WS-Federation) or the Issuer property (for SAML-P) when making a sign-in request. The App ID URI must be a unique value in your organization’s Azure AD.

Note: When enabling an app for external users, the value of the App ID URI of the app must be an address in one of your directory’s verified domains. As a result, it cannot be a URN. This safeguard prevents other organizations from specifying (and taking) unique property that belongs to your organization. During development, you can change your App ID URI to a location in your organization’s initial domain (if you haven’t verified a custom/vanity domain), and update your app to use this new value. The initial domain is the 3-level domain that you create during sign up, such as contoso.onmicrosoft.com.

trans-unit.source: App URL
trans-unit.target: App URL

trans-unit.source:
The address of a web page where users can sign in and use your app. Required property in the Add Application wizard.

Note: The value set for this property in the Add Application wizard is also set as the value of the Reply URL.
trans-unit.target:
The address of a web page where users can sign in and use your app. Required property in the Add Application wizard.

Note: The value set for this property in the Add Application wizard is also set as the value of the Reply URL.

trans-unit.source: Reply URL
trans-unit.target: Reply URL

trans-unit.source:
The physical address of your app. Azure AD sends a token with the single sign-on response to this address. During first registration in the Add Application wizard, the value set for the App URL is also set as the value of the Reply URL. When making a sign in request, use the Reply URL value to set the wreply property (for WS-Federation) or the AssertionConsumerServiceURL property (for SAML-P).

Note: When enabling an app for external users, the Reply URL must be an https:// address.
trans-unit.target:
The physical address of your app. Azure AD sends a token with the single sign-on response to this address. During first registration in the Add Application wizard, the value set for the App URL is also set as the value of the Reply URL. When making a sign in request, use the Reply URL value to set the wreply property (for WS-Federation) or the AssertionConsumerServiceURL property (for SAML-P).

Note: When enabling an app for external users, the Reply URL must be an https:// address.

trans-unit.source: Federation Metadata URL
trans-unit.target: Federation Metadata URL

trans-unit.source:
(Optional). Represents the physical URL of the federation metadata document for your app. It is required to support SAML-P sign out. Azure AD downloads the metadata document that is hosted at this endpoint and uses it to discover the public portion of the certificate that you use to verify the signature on your sign-out requests and your app’s sign-out URL. You cannot configure this property when you first add your app. It can only be configured later.

Note: If you need to support SAML-P sign-out, but you do not have a federation metadata endpoint for your app, contact Customer Support for other options.
trans-unit.target:
(Optional). Represents the physical URL of the federation metadata document for your app. It is required to support SAML-P sign out. Azure AD downloads the metadata document that is hosted at this endpoint and uses it to discover the public portion of the certificate that you use to verify the signature on your sign-out requests and your app’s sign-out URL. You cannot configure this property when you first add your app. It can only be configured later.

Note: If you need to support SAML-P sign-out, but you do not have a federation metadata endpoint for your app, contact Customer Support for other options.

trans-unit.source: Property
trans-unit.target: Property

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Client ID
trans-unit.target: Client ID

trans-unit.source:
The unique identifier for your app. You need to use this identifier in calls to the Graph API or other web APIs registered with Azure AD. Azure AD automatically generates this value during app registration and it cannot be changed.

To enable your app to access the directory (for read or write access) through the Graph API, you need a Client ID and a key (known in OAuth 2.0 as a client secret). Your app uses the Client ID and key to request an access token from the Azure AD OAuth 2.0 token endpoint. (To view all Azure AD endpoints, in the command bar, click View endpoints.) When using the Graph API to get or set (change) directory data, your app uses this access token in the Authorize header of the request to the Graph API.
trans-unit.target:
The unique identifier for your app. You need to use this identifier in calls to the Graph API or other web APIs registered with Azure AD. Azure AD automatically generates this value during app registration and it cannot be changed.

To enable your app to access the directory (for read or write access) through the Graph API, you need a Client ID and a key (known in OAuth 2.0 as a client secret). Your app uses the Client ID and key to request an access token from the Azure AD OAuth 2.0 token endpoint. (To view all Azure AD endpoints, in the command bar, click View endpoints.) When using the Graph API to get or set (change) directory data, your app uses this access token in the Authorize header of the request to the Graph API.

trans-unit.source: Keys
trans-unit.target: Keys

trans-unit.source: If your app reads or writes data in Azure AD, such as data that is made available through the Graph API, your app needs a key.
trans-unit.target: If your app reads or writes data in Azure AD, such as data that is made available through the Graph API, your app needs a key.

trans-unit.source: When you request an access token to call the Graph API, your app supplies its Client ID and Key.
trans-unit.target: When you request an access token to call the Graph API, your app supplies its Client ID and Key.

trans-unit.source: The token endpoint uses the ID and key to authenticate your app before issuing the access token.
trans-unit.target: The token endpoint uses the ID and key to authenticate your app before issuing the access token.

trans-unit.source: You can create multiple keys to address key rollover scenarios.
trans-unit.target: You can create multiple keys to address key rollover scenarios.

trans-unit.source: And, you can delete keys that are expired, compromised, or no longer in use.
trans-unit.target: And, you can delete keys that are expired, compromised, or no longer in use.

trans-unit.source: Manage Access
trans-unit.target: Manage Access

trans-unit.source:
Choose from one of three different access levels: single sign-on (SSO), SSO and read directory data, or SSO and read/write directory data. You can also remove access. For more information about directory access, see Application Access Levels.

Note: Changes to the directory access level of your app apply only to your directory. The changes do not apply to customers who have granted access to your app.
trans-unit.target:
Choose from one of three different access levels: single sign-on (SSO), SSO and read directory data, or SSO and read/write directory data. You can also remove access. For more information about directory access, see Application Access Levels.

Note: Changes to the directory access level of your app apply only to your directory. The changes do not apply to customers who have granted access to your app.

trans-unit.source: Property
trans-unit.target: Property

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Redirect URI
trans-unit.target: Redirect URI

trans-unit.source: The URI to which Azure AD will redirect the user-agent in response to an OAuth 2.0 authorization request.
trans-unit.target: The URI to which Azure AD will redirect the user-agent in response to an OAuth 2.0 authorization request.

trans-unit.source: The value does not need to be a physical endpoint, but must be a valid URI.
trans-unit.target: The value does not need to be a physical endpoint, but must be a valid URI.
